Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The Effects of Robots on the Economy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides funding for the first data to be systematically collected on the annual expenditures on robots by American manufacturing establishments. Robot technology has advanced rapidly in a number of areas, and the cost of using robots has declined. As a result, more and more U.S. businesses are using robots for a wide range of tasks, which has led to speculation about whether robots will replace workers, or have other impacts on our economy and society. The data collected by this project will help researchers to investigate how expenditures on robots affect a wide range of economic outcomes and help policy makers to assess possible policy responses.

Existing surveys rely instead on national or industry level counts of robot shipments. This project collects establishment level data on robot expenditures from an additional question added to the Annual Survey of Manufacturers (ASM). The ASM samples approximately 50,000 manufacturing establishments annually, and the population of approximately 300,000 manufacturing establishments every five years. This project will use establishment-level data on robot expenditures to study the effect of robot expenditures on the number and wages of workers at these establishments, establishment-level revenues, and other establishment-level measures of productivity. The data will also be aggregated to local and regional levels to study how expenditures on robots affect regional economies, including regional-level measures of manufacturing value-added, labor force participation, and unemployment, among others. Moreover, as the data will be collected via a recurring annual survey, it is possible to study robot expenditures trends, within-establishment effects of robot expenditures on establishment-level outcomes, and longer-term effects of robot expenditures on labor, productivity, and regional economies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided funding for the creation and cognitive testing of questions on the purchase and use of industrial robots by American manufacturing establishments. A detailed description of the  cognitive testing process is provided in a U.S. Census Bureau working paper by Buffington, Miranda and Seamans (2018) available here: https://www2.census.gov/ces/wp/2018/CES-WP-18-44.pdf. The working paper also provides the final list of questions.

As a result of the cognitive testing, three questions on robotics are now included in the 2018 Annual Survey of Manufacturers (ASM), administered by the U.S. Census Bureau. These include questions about: (1) capital expenditures for new and used industrial robotic equipment at the plant; (2) the number of industrial robots in operation at the plant; and (3) the number of industrial robots purchased for the plant in the past year. These questions are the first-ever plant-level questions on robotics included in a U.S. government survey. The ASM samples approximately 50,000 manufacturing establishments annually, and the population of approximately 300,000 manufacturing establishments every five years. Aggregated data from these questions will be made available to the public in 2020.

Robot technology has advanced rapidly in a number of areas, and the cost of using robots has declined. As a result, more and more U.S. businesses are using robots for a wide range of tasks, which has led to speculation about whether robots will replace workers, or have other impacts on our economy and society. The robotics questions that were created by this project will result in data that can be used by government employees and academic researchers to investigate how expenditures on robots affect a wide range of economic outcomes, and help policy makers to assess possible policy responses.

For example, researchers could use the resulting establishment-level data on robot expenditures to study the effect of robot expenditures on the number and wages of workers at these establishments, establishment-level revenues, and other establishment-level measures of productivity. The data can also be aggregated to local and regional levels to study how expenditures on robots affect regional economies, including regional-level measures of manufacturing value-added, labor force participation, and unemployment, among others. Moreover, as the data will be collected via a recurring annual survey, it may be possible to study robot expenditures trends, within-establishment effects of robot expenditures on establishment-level outcomes, and longer-term effects of robot expenditures on labor, productivity, and regional economies.
